repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Laguna de Bay Institutional
            Strengthening and Community Participation Project : Main report

abstracts.cdata!:
The Laguna de Bay Institutional
            Strengthening and Community Participation Project had a
            moderately satisfactory outcome with substantial risk to
            development outcome. Performance by the Bank and the
            borrower was moderately satisfactory as well. There were
            three major IBRD-related changes: (a) four extensions of
            closing date; (b) Additional Financing of US$10 million; and
            (c) partial cancellation of US$4.5 million. The report
            outlines six lessons learned from the project and are as
            follows: (1) Catalyzing community support through education,
            field days and provision of grant funding demonstrated the
            potential for civil society support. (2) The Philippines is
            replete with laws and regulations relating to pollution,
            liquid and solid waste management, but enforcement has been
            inconsistent. (3) More attention needs to be given to the
            operation and maintenance of sub-project facilities. There
            are a number of cases under the project where sustainability
            suffered. (4) Solid waste/garbage landfill capacity.
            Sanitary landfill facilities are another gap in
            environmental management infrastructure. Although many Local
            Government Unites within the Laguna de Bay (LGUs) have set
            up materials recovery facilities and composting facilities
            under the project, they do not have adequate capacity in
            sanitary landfills for their residual (unrecyclable) wastes.
            (5) Private sector participation in watershed management.
            The investment required to rehabilitate the watershed is
            huge and the Laguna Lake Development Authority (LLDA)/LGU
            partnership is not sufficient to achieve this objective.
            Private sector partnership (PSP) modalities such as
            build-operate-transfer or develop-build-operate and
            partnership with LGUs to implement infrastructure projects
            are clearly a priority for the Laguna de Bay watershed. (6)
            Integrated approach to watershed management. Future projects
            should undertake a comprehensive watershed management
            approach by complementing measures to reduce industrial
            pollution with actions to curb waste emanating from domestic
            households and informal settlements along riverbanks and
            shore land areas, and from soil erosion and sedimentation
            resulting from deforestation and land use change.

repnme.cdata!:
Philippines - Additional financing for the
            Laguna de Bay Institutional Strengthening and Community
            Participation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Additional
            financing (AF) for the Laguna de Bay Institutional
            Strengthening and Community Participation (LICOP) Project
            for Philippines is to assist the Laguna Lake Development
            Authority (LLDA), Local Government Units (LGUs) and other
            stakeholders to improve the environmental quality of the
            Laguna de Bay watershed. The AF will help finance the costs
            associated with scaling up of priority environmental
            subprojects implemented by the participating LGUs financed
            under component one of the LISCOP project to address
            pressing environmental issues besetting the lake and its
            watershed. In particular, the AF will support the
            implementation of thirty seven pipeline subprojects
            identified in the Lake Environmental Action Plan (LEAP),
            which was prepared and completed in each of the twenty four
            micro-catchments in the Laguna Lake under the LISCOP
            project. The AF will not only expand LGU coverage and
            increase project benefits; it will also help address the
            Philippine Supreme Court ruling in December 2008 mandating
            concerned agencies to clean up and rehabilitate the Manila
            Bay, which receives water from Laguna Lake through the Pasig
            River. There will be no change in the project development
            objective. No significant changes are also envisaged to the
            original project design. The institutional and
            implementation arrangements of the AF will remain the same
            as the original project.
